movie.title: Casablanca
movie.basedOn: Everybody Comes to Rick’s (stage play); written by Murray Burnett and Joan Alison

scene.camera: FADE IN: LONG SHOT — REVOLVING GLOBE
scene.setting: A revolving globe. When it stops revolving it turns briefly into a contour map of Europe, then into a flat map. Superimposed over this map are scenes of refugees fleeing from all sections of Europe by foot, wagon, auto, and boat, and all converging upon one point on the tip of Africa -- Casablanca. Arrows on the map illustrate the routes taken as the voice of a NARRATOR describes the migration.

sp.speaker: NARRATOR
sp.diag: With the coming of the Second World War, many eyes in imprisoned Europe turned hopefully, or desperately, toward the freedom of the Americas. Lisbon became the great embarkation point. But not everybody could get to Lisbon directly, and so, a tortuous, roundabout refugee trail sprang up. Paris to Marseilles, across the Mediterranean to Oran, then by train, or auto, or foot, across the rim of Africa to Casablanca in French Morocco. Here, the fortunate ones, through money, or influence, or luck, might obtain exit visas and scurry to Lisbon, and from Lisbon to the New World. But the others wait in Casablanca -- and wait -- and wait -- and wait. The narrator's voice fade away...

scene.setting: EXT. OLD MOORISH SECTION OF THE CITY - DAY At first only the turrets and rooftops are visible against a torrid sky. The facades of the Moorish buildings give way to a narrow, twisting street crowded with the polyglot life of a native quarter. The intense desert sun holds the scene in a torpid tranquility. Activity is unhurried and sounds are muted.
INT. POLICE STATION - DAY A POLICE OFFICER takes a piece of paper from the typewriter, turns to a microphone, and reads.

sp.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
sp.diag: To all officers! Two German couriers carrying important official documents murdered on train from Oran. Murderer and possible accomplices headed for Casablanca. Round up all suspicious characters and search them for stolen documents. Important!

scene.setting: EXT. A STREET IN THE OLD MOORISH SECTION - DAY An officer BLOWS his whistle several times. There is pandemonium as native guards begin to round up people. A police car, full of officers, with SIREN BLARING, screams through the street and stops in the market. Some try to escape but are caught by the police and loaded into a police wagon. At a street corner TWO POLICEMEN stop a white CIVILIAN and question him.

sp.speaker: FIRST POLICEMAN
sp.diag: May we see your papers?

sp.speaker: CIVILIAN
sp.diag: nervously I don't think I have them on me.

sp.speaker: FIRST POLICEMAN
sp.diag: In that case, we'll have to ask you to come along.

sp.speaker: CIVILIAN
sp.diag: Wait. It's just possible that I -\- Yes, here they are.

scene.dir: He brings out his papers. The second policeman examines them.

sp.speaker: SECOND POLICEMAN
sp.diag: These papers expired three weeks ago. You'll have to come along.

scene.dir: Suddenly the civilian breaks away and starts to run wildly down the street. The policeman SHOUTS "Halt", but the civilian keeps going. JAN and ANNINA BRANDEL, a very young and attractive refugee couple from Bulgaria, watch as the civilian passes. They've been thrust by circumstances from a simple country life into an unfamiliar and hectic world. A shot RINGS out, and the man falls to the ground. Above him, painted on the wall, is a large poster of Marshal Petain, which reads: "Je tiens mes promesses, meme celles des autres." The policeman frantically searches the body, but only finds Free French literature.

scene.setting: EXT. PALAIS DE JUSTICE - DAY We see an inscription carved in a marble block along the roofline of the building: "Liberte, Egalite, Fraternite" We see the the facade, French in architecture, then the high-vaulted entrance which is inscribed "Palais de Justice". At the entrance the arrested suspects are led in by the police.

EXT. SIDEWALK CAFE - DAY A middle-aged ENGLISH COUPLE sit at a table just off the square, and observe the commotion across the way in front of the Palais de Justice. The police van pulls up. The rear doors are opened and people stream out. A EUROPEAN man, sitting at a table nearby, watches the English couple more closely than the scene on the street.

sp.speaker: ENGLISHWOMAN
sp.diag: What on earth's going on there?

sp.speaker: ENGLISHMAN
sp.diag: I don't know, my dear. The European walks over to the couple.

sp.speaker: EUROPEAN
sp.diag: Pardon, pardon, Monsieur, pardon Madame, have you not heard?

sp.speaker: ENGLISHMAN
sp.diag: We hear very little, and we understand even less.

sp.speaker: EUROPEAN
sp.diag: Two German couriers were found murdered in the desert -\- the unoccupied desert. This is the customary roundup of refugees, liberals, and uh, of course, a beautiful young girl for Monsieur Renault, the Prefect of Police.

scene.setting: EXT. PALAIS DE JUSTICE - DAY Suspects are herded out of the van, and into the Palais de Justice.

sp.speaker: EUROPEAN
sp.diag: Unfortunately, along with these unhappy refugees the scum of Europe has gravitated to Casablanca. Some of them have been waiting years for a visa.

scene.dir: He puts his left arm compassionately around the Englishman, and reaches behind the man with his right hand.

sp.speaker: EUROPEAN
sp.diag: I beg of you, Monsieur, watch yourself. Be on guard. This place is full of vultures, vultures everywhere, everywhere.

scene.dir: The Englishman seems to be taken aback by this sudden display of concern.

sp.speaker: ENGLISHMAN
sp.diag: Ha, ha, thank you, thank you very much.

sp.speaker: EUROPEAN
sp.diag: Not at all. Au revoir, Monsieur. Au revoir, Madame.

scene.dir: He leaves. The Englishman, still a trifle disconcerted by the European's action, watches him as he leaves.

sp.speaker: ENGLISHMAN
sp.diag: Au revoir. Amusing little fellow. Waiter!

scene.dir: As he pats both his breast and pants pockets he realizes there is something missing.

sp.speaker: ENGLISHMAN
sp.diag: Oh. How silly of me.

sp.speaker: ENGLISHWOMAN
sp.diag: What, dear?

sp.speaker: ENGLISHMAN
sp.diag: I've left my wallet in the hotel.

sp.speaker: ENGLISHWOMAN
sp.diag: Oh.

scene.dir: Suddenly the Englishman looks off in the direction of the departed European, the clouds of suspicion gathering. Interrupting overhead is the DRONE of a low flying airplane. They look up.

scene.setting: EXT. OVERHEAD SHOT - DAY An airplane cuts its motor for landing.

EXT. PALAIS DE JUSTICE - DAY Refugees wait in line outside the Palais de Justice. Their upturned gaze follows the flight of the plane. In their faces is revealed one hope they all have in common, and the plane is the symbol of that hope. Jan and Annina look up at the plane.

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: wistfully Perhaps tomorrow we'll be on that plane.

scene.setting: EXT. OVERHEAD SHOT - DAY The plane SWOOPS down past a sign atop a building at the edge of the airport. The sign reads "Rick's Cafe Americain."

EXT. AIRFIELD - DAY As the plane lands a swastika on its tail is clearly visible. It taxis to a stop as a group of officers march into formation in front of it. Behind them stand a detail of native soldiers keeping guard. In the group is CAPTAIN LOUIS RENAULT, a French officer appointed by Vichy as Prefect of Police in Casablanca. He is a handsome, middle-aged Frenchman, debonair and gay, but withal a shrewd and alert official. With him are HERR HEINZE, the German consul, CAPTAIN TONELLI, an Italian officer, and LIEUTENANT CASSELLE, Renault's aide. When the plane door opens, the first passenger to step out is a tall, middle-aged, pale German with a smile that seems more the result of a frozen face muscle than a cheerful disposition. On any occasion when MAJOR STRASSER is crossed, his expression hardens into iron. Herr Heinze steps up to him with upraised arm.

sp.speaker: HEINZE
sp.diag: Heil Hitler.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: Heil Hitler.

scene.dir: They shake hands.

sp.speaker: HEINZE
sp.diag: It is very good to see you again, Major Strasser.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: Thank you. Thank you.

scene.dir: Heinze introduces Strasser to Renault.

sp.speaker: HEINZE
sp.diag: May I present Captain Renault, Police Prefect of Casablanca. Major Strasser.

scene.dir: Renault salutes.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Unoccupied France welcomes you to Casablanca.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: in perfect English, smiling Thank you, Captain. It's very good to be here.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Major Strasser, my aide, Lieutenant Casselle.

scene.dir: As they acknowledge each other, Captain Tonelli barges in front of Casselle and salutes Strasser.

sp.speaker: TONELLI
sp.diag: Captain Tonelli, the Italian service, at your command, Major.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: That is kind of you.

scene.dir: But Tonelli gets no further than that as Strasser turns again to Renault. They walk away from the plane, Heinze following, with Casselle and Tonelli bringing up the rear, engaged in a heated exchange of words.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: You may find the climate of Casablanca a trifle warm, Major.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: Oh, we Germans must get used to all climates, from Russia to the Sahara. But perhaps you were not referring to the weather.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: sidesteps the implication with a smile What else, my dear Major?

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: casually By the way, the murder of the couriers, what has been done?

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Realizing the importance of the case, my men are rounding up twice the usual number of suspects.

sp.speaker: HEINZE
sp.diag: We already know who the murderer is.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: Good. Is he in custody?

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Oh, there is no hurry. Tonight he'll be at Rick's. Everybody comes to Rick's.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: I have already heard about this cafe, and also about Mr. Rick himself.

scene.setting: EXT. RICK'S CAFE - NIGHT The neon sign above the door is brightly lit. Customers arrive and go in through the front door. From inside we hear sounds of MUSIC and LAUGHTER. The song is "It Had to Be You." Again we isolate on the neon sign. INSERT SIGN: "Rick's Cafe Americain". We follow a group of customers inside.

INT. RICK'S CAFE - MAIN ROOM - NIGHT Rick's is an expensive and chic nightclub which definitely possesses an air of sophistication and intrigue. SAM, a middle-aged Negro, sits on a stool before a small, salmon-colored piano on wheels, playing and singing while accompanied by a small orchestra. All about him there is the HUM of voices, CHATTER and LAUGHTER. The occupants of the room are varied. There are Europeans in their dinner jackets, their women beautifully begowned and bejeweled. There are Moroccans in silk robes. Turks wearing fezzes. Levantines. Naval officers. Members of the Foreign Legion, distinguished by their kepis. Two men sit at a table.

sp.speaker: MAN
sp.diag: Waiting, waiting, waiting. I'll never get out of here. I'll die in Casablanca.

scene.dir: His companion seems uninterested in his dilemma. Sympathy is evidently in short supply in Casablanca. At another table a very well-dressed WOMAN talks to a MOOR. She has a bracelet on her wrist. No other jewelry.

sp.speaker: WOMAN
sp.diag: But can't you make it just a little more? Please.

sp.speaker: MOOR
sp.diag: I'm sorry, Madame, but diamonds are a drug on the market. Everybody sells diamonds. There are diamonds everywhere. Two thousand, four hundred.

sp.speaker: WOMAN
sp.diag: All right.

scene.dir: On to another table where two CONSPIRATORS talk.

sp.speaker: CONSPIRATOR
sp.diag: The trucks are waiting, the men are waiting. Everything is --

scene.dir: He stops abruptly as two German officers walk by. A REFUGEE and another MAN converse at another table.

sp.speaker: MAN
sp.diag: It's the fishing smack Santiago. It leaves at one tomorrow night, here from the end of La Medina. Third boat.

sp.speaker: REFUGEE
sp.diag: Thank you, oh, thank you.

sp.speaker: MAN
sp.diag: And bring fifteen thousand francs in cash. Remember, in cash.

scene.dir: On the way to the bar we pass several tables and hear a Babel of foreign tongues. Here and there we catch a scattered phrase or sentence in English. SACHA, a friendly young Russian bartender, hands a drink to a customer with the Russian equivalent of "Bottoms Up." The customer answers with "Cheerio." CARL, the waiter, is a fat, jovial German refugee with spectacles. He walks, tray in hand, to a private door, over which ABDUL, a large, burly man, stands guard.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: Open up, Abdul.

sp.speaker: ABDUL
sp.diag: respectfully Yes, Herr Professor.

scene.dir: Abdul opens the door and Carl goes into the gambling room.

scene.setting: INT. RICK'S CAFE - GAMBLING ROOM - NIGHT Their is much activity at the various tables. At one table TWO WOMEN and a MAN play cards. They glance at another table. One of them calls to Carl.

sp.speaker: FIRST WOMAN
sp.diag: Uh, waiter.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: Yes, Madame?

sp.speaker: FIRST WOMAN
sp.diag: Will you ask Rick if he'll have a drink with us?

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: Madame, he never drinks with customers. Never. I have never seen him.

sp.speaker: SECOND WOMAN
sp.diag: disappointedly What makes saloon-keepers so snobbish?

sp.speaker: MAN
sp.diag: to Carl Perhaps if you told him I ran the second largest banking house in Amsterdam.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: The second largest? That wouldn't impress Rick. The leading banker in Amsterdam is now the pastry chef in our kitchen.

sp.speaker: MAN
sp.diag: We have something to look forward to.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: And his father is the bellboy.

scene.dir: Carl laughs. The overseer walks up to a table with a paper in his hand. Then we see a drink and a man's hand, but nothing more. The overseer places a check on the table. The hand picks up the check and writes on it, in pencil, "Okay-Rick." The overseer takes the check. We now see RICK, sitting at a table alone playing solitaire chess. Rick is an American of indeterminate age. There is no expression on his face, complete deadpan. There is a commotion at the door as people attempt to come into the gambling room. He nods approval to Abdul. Then a GERMAN appears in the doorway. Abdul looks to Rick who glances back toward the open door and nods "no". Abdul starts to close the door on the man.

sp.speaker: ABDUL
sp.diag: I'm sorry sir, this is a private room.

sp.speaker: GERMAN
sp.diag: Of all the nerve! Who do you think -- I know there's gambling in there! There's no secret. You dare not keep me out of here!

scene.dir: The man tries to push his way through the door as Rick walks up.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: coldly Yes? What's the trouble?

sp.speaker: ABDUL
sp.diag: This gentleman --

scene.dir: The German interrupts and waves his card.

sp.speaker: GERMAN
sp.diag: I've been in every gambling room between Honolulu and Berlin and if you think I'm going to be kept out of a saloon like this, you're very much mistaken.

scene.dir: At this moment UGARTE, a small, thin man with a nervous air, tries to squeeze through the doorway blocked by the German. If he were an American, Ugarte would look like a tout. He gets through and passes Rick.

sp.speaker: UGARTE
sp.diag: Uh, excuse me, please. Hello, Rick.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: softly Hello Ugarte.

scene.dir: Rick looks at the German calmly, takes the card out of his hand, and tears it up.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Your cash is good at the bar.

sp.speaker: GERMAN
sp.diag: What! Do you know who I am?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I do. You're lucky the bar's open to you.

sp.speaker: GERMAN
sp.diag: This is outrageous. I shall report it to the Angriff!

scene.dir: The German storms off, tossing the pieces of his card into the air behind him. Rick meets Ugarte on his way back to his table.

sp.speaker: UGARTE
sp.diag: fawning Huh. You know, Rick, watching you just now with the Deutsches Bank, one would think you'd been doing this all your life.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: stiffening Well, what makes you think I haven't?

sp.speaker: UGARTE
sp.diag: vaguely Oh, nothing. But when you first came to Casablanca, I thought --

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: coldly -- You thought what?

scene.dir: Fearing to offend Rick, Ugarte laughs.

sp.speaker: UGARTE
sp.diag: What right do I have to think? Ugarte pulls out a chair at Rick's table.

sp.speaker: UGARTE
sp.diag: May I? Too bad about those two German couriers, wasn't it?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: indifferently They got a lucky break. Yesterday they were just two German clerks. Today they're the 'Honored Dead'.

sp.speaker: UGARTE
sp.diag: You are a very cynical person, Rick, if you'll forgive me for saying so.

scene.dir: Ugarte sits down.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: shortly I forgive you. A waiter comes up to the table with a tray of drinks. He places one before Ugarte.

sp.speaker: UGARTE
sp.diag: Thank you. to Rick Will you have a drink with me please?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: No.

sp.speaker: UGARTE
sp.diag: I forgot. You never drink with -- to waiter I'll have another, please. to Rick, sadly You despise me, don't you?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: indifferently If I gave you any thought, I probably would.

sp.speaker: UGARTE
sp.diag: But why? Oh, you object to the kind of business I do, huh? But think of all those poor refugees who must rot in this place if I didn't help them. That's not so bad. Through ways of my own I provide them with exit visas.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: For a price, Ugarte, for a price.

sp.speaker: UGARTE
sp.diag: But think of all the poor devils who cannot meet Renault's price. I get it for them for half. Is that so parasitic?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I don't mind a parasite. I object to a cut-rate one.

sp.speaker: UGARTE
sp.diag: Well, Rick, after tonight I'll be through with the whole business, and I am leaving finally this Casablanca.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Who did you bribe for your visa? Renault or yourself?

sp.speaker: UGARTE
sp.diag: ironically Myself. I found myself much more reasonable. He takes an envelope from his pocket and lays it on the table.

sp.speaker: UGARTE
sp.diag: Look, Rick, do you know what this is? Something that even you have never seen. Letters of transit signed by General de Gaulle. Cannot be rescinded, not even questioned.

scene.dir: Rick appears ready to take them form Ugarte.

sp.speaker: UGARTE
sp.diag: One moment. Tonight I'll be selling those for more money than even I have ever dreamed of, and then, addio Casablanca! You know, Rick, I have many friends in Casablanca, but somehow, just because you despise me you're the only one I trust. Will you keep these for me? Please.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: For how long?

sp.speaker: UGARTE
sp.diag: Perhaps an hour, perhaps a little longer.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I don't want them here overnight.

sp.speaker: UGARTE
sp.diag: Don't be afraid of that. Please keep them for me. Thank you. I knew I could trust you.

scene.dir: Rick takes them. Ugarte leaves the table just as the waiter comes up.

sp.speaker: UGARTE
sp.diag: Oh, waiter. I'll be expecting some people. If anybody asks for me, I'll be right here.

sp.speaker: WAITER
sp.diag: Yes, Monsieur.

scene.dir: The waiter leaves. Ugarte turns to Rick.

sp.speaker: UGARTE
sp.diag: Rick, I hope you are more impressed with me now, huh? If you'll forgive me, I'll share my good luck with your roulette wheel.

scene.dir: He starts across the floor.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Just a moment.

scene.dir: Ugarte stops as Rick comes up to him.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Yeah, I heard a rumor that those German couriers were carrying letters of transit.

scene.dir: Ugarte hesitates for a moment.

sp.speaker: UGARTE
sp.diag: Huh? I heard that rumor, too. Poor devils.

scene.dir: Rick looks at Ugarte steadily.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: slowly Yes, you're right, Ugarte. I am a little more impressed with you.

scene.dir: Rick leaves the gambling room and goes into the main room.

scene.setting: INT. RICK'S CAFE - MAIN ROOM - NIGHT Rick makes his way over to Sam, who plays and sings the "Knock Wood" number, accompanied by the orchestra. The cafe is in semi-darkness. The spotlight is on Sam, and every time the orchestra comes in on the "Knock Wood" business, the spotlight swings over to the orchestra. During one of the periods when the spotlight is on the orchestra, Rick slips the letters of transit into the piano. FERRARI, owner of the Blue Parrot, a competing night spot, comes into the cafe, sits down, and watches Sam. Then he sees Rick and they smile at each other. At the end of the number Ferrari goes to the bar to speak to Rick.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: Hello, Rick.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Hello, Ferrari. How's business at the Blue Parrot?

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: Fine, but I would like to buy your cafe.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: It's not for sale.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: You haven't heard my offer.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: It's not for sale at any price.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: What do you want for Sam?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I don't buy or sell human beings.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: That's too bad. That's Casablanca's leading commodity. In refugees alone we could make a fortune if you would work with me through the black market.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Suppose you run your business and let me run mine.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: Suppose we ask Sam. Maybe he'd like to make a change.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Suppose we do.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: My dear Rick, when will you realize that in this world today isolationism is no longer a practical policy?

scene.dir: Rick and Ferrari walk over to the piano.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Sam, Ferrari wants you to work for him at the Blue Parrot.

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: I like it fine here.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: He'll double what I pay you.

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: Yeah, but I ain't got time to spend the money I make here.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Sorry.

scene.dir: Apparently satisfied, Ferrari walks away. Back at the bar, YVONNE, an attractive young French woman, sits on a stool drinking brandy. Sacha, who looks at her with lovesick eyes, fills her tumbler.

sp.speaker: SACHA
sp.diag: The boss's private stock. Because, Yvonne, I loff you.

sp.speaker: YVONNE
sp.diag: morosely Oh, shut up.

sp.speaker: SACHA
sp.diag: fondly All right, all right. For you, Yvonne, I shot opp, because, Yvonne, I loff you. Uh oh.

scene.dir: Rick saunters over and leans on the bar, next to Yvonne. He pays no attention to her. She looks at him bitterly, without saying a word.s

sp.speaker: SACHA
sp.diag: Oh, Monsieur Rick, Monsieur Rick. Some Germans, boom, boom, boom, boom, gave this check. Is it all right?

scene.dir: Rick looks the check over and tears it up. Yvonne has never taken her eyes off Rick.

sp.speaker: YVONNE
sp.diag: Where were you last night?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: That's so long ago, I don't remember.

sp.speaker: YVONNE
sp.diag: Will I see you tonight?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: matter-of-factly I never make plans that far ahead. Yvonne turns, looks at Sacha, and extends her glass to him.

sp.speaker: YVONNE
sp.diag: Give me another.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Sacha, she's had enough.

sp.speaker: YVONNE
sp.diag: Don't listen to him, Sacha. Fill it up.

sp.speaker: SACHA
sp.diag: Yvonne, I loff you, but he pays me.

scene.dir: Yvonne wheels on Rick with drunken fury.

sp.speaker: YVONNE
sp.diag: Rick, I'm sick and tired of having you --

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: -- Sacha, call a cab.

sp.speaker: SACHA
sp.diag: Yes, boss.

scene.dir: Rick takes Yvonne by the arm.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Come on, we're going to get your coat.

sp.speaker: YVONNE
sp.diag: Take your hands off me!

scene.dir: He pulls her along toward the door.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: No. You're going home. You've had a little too much to drink.

scene.setting: EXT. RICK'S CAFE - NIGHT Sacha stands at the curb on the street in front of Rick's and signals for a cab.

sp.speaker: SACHA
sp.diag: Taxi!

scene.dir: Soon one pulls up. Rick and Yvonne come out of the cafe. He puts a coat over her shoulders and she objects violently.

sp.speaker: YVONNE
sp.diag: Who do you think you are, pushing me around? What a fool I was to fall for a man like you.

scene.dir: Rick and Yvonne approach the waiting cab.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: to Sacha You'd better go with her, Sacha, to be sure she gets home.

sp.speaker: SACHA
sp.diag: Yes, boss.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: And come right back.

sp.speaker: SACHA
sp.diag: his face falling Yes, boss.

scene.dir: Rick stands and looks up at the revolving beacon light from the airport. It intermittently sheds its light on Rick's face. Renault sits at a table on the cafe terrace, watching this evening's performance.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Hello, Rick.

scene.dir: Rick walks over to him.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Hello, Louis.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: How extravagant you are, throwing away women like that. Someday they may be scarce.

scene.dir: Rick sits down at the table.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: amused You know, I think now I shall pay a call on Yvonne, maybe get her on the rebound, eh?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: When it comes to women, you're a true democrat.

scene.dir: As they talk, Captain Tonelli and Lieutenant Casselle walk by toward the entrance of the cafe. Casselle talks non-stop and Tonelli tries. They both stop, salute Renault, and walk into the cafe.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: If he gets a word in it'll be a major Italian victory. Rick laughs. Rick and Renault look up when they hear the BUZZ of a plane taking off from the adjacent airfield. The plane flies directly over their heads.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: The plane to Lisbon. pause You would like to be on it?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: curtly Why? What's in Lisbon?

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: The clipper to America. Rick doesn't answer. His look isn't a happy one.

scene.dir: Rick doesn't answer. His look isn't a happy one.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: I have often speculated on why you don't return to America. Did you abscond with the church funds? Did you run off with a senator's wife? I like to think you killed a man. It's the romantic in me.

scene.dir: Rick still looks in the direction of the airport.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: It was a combination of all three.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: And what in heaven's name brought you to Casablanca?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: My health. I came to Casablanca for the waters.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Waters? What waters? We're in the desert.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I was misinformed.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Huh!

scene.dir: EMIL, the croupier, comes out of the cafe and walks over to Rick.

sp.speaker: EMIL
sp.diag: Excuse me, Monsieur Rick, but a gentleman inside has won twenty thousand francs. The cashier would like some money.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Well, I'll get it from the safe.

sp.speaker: EMIL
sp.diag: I am so upset, Monsieur Rick. You know I can't understand --

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: -- Forget it, Emil. Mistakes like that happen all the time.

sp.speaker: EMIL
sp.diag: I'm awfully sorry.

scene.dir: The three men enter the cafe.

scene.setting: INT. RICK'S CAFE - MAIN ROOM - NIGHT They pass Sam at the piano. He's playing "Baby Face". Rick pats Sam on the shoulder.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Rick, there's going to be some excitement here tonight. We are going to make an arrest in your cafe.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: somewhat annoyed What, again?

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: This is no ordinary arrest.

scene.dir: A murderer, no less. Rick's eyes react. Involuntarily, they glance toward the gambling room. Renault catches the look.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: If you are thinking of warning him, don't put yourself out. He cannot possibly escape.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I stick my neck out for nobody.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: A wise foreign policy.

scene.dir: They start upstairs to Rick's office, passing Casselle who is still haranguing Tonelli.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: You know, Rick, we could have made this arrest earlier in the evening at the Blue Parrot, but out of my high regard for you we are staging it here. It will amuse your customers.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Our entertainment is enough.

scene.dir: They go inside the office.

scene.setting: INT. RICK'S CAFE - OFFICE - NIGHT Rick opens up the safe in a small, dark room just off the office. Only Rick's shadow can be seen getting the money out.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Rick, we are to have an important guest tonight, Major Strasser of the Third Reich, no less. We want him to be here when we make the arrest. A little demonstration of the efficiency of my administration.

scene.dir: Rick moves out of the shadows and into view.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I see. And what's Strasser doing here? He certainly didn't come all the way to Casablanca to witness a demonstration of your efficiency.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Perhaps not.

scene.dir: He gives the money to Emil.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Here you are.

sp.speaker: EMIL
sp.diag: It shall not happen again, Monsieur.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: That's all right.

scene.dir: Emil departs.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Louis, you've got something on your mind. Why don't you spill it?

scene.dir: Rick closes the door to the office, then goes over to close the safe.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: How observant you are. As a matter of fact, I wanted to give you a word of advice.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Yeah? Have a brandy?

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Thank you. Rick, there are many exit visas sold in this cafe, but we know that you have never sold one. That is the reason we permit you to remain open.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I thought it was because we let you win at roulette.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: That is another reason. There is a man who's arrived in Casablanca on his way to America. He will offer a fortune to anyone who will furnish him with an exit visa.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Yeah? What's his name?

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Victor Laszlo.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Victor Laszlo?

scene.dir: Renault watches Rick's reaction.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Rick, that is the first time I have ever seen you so impressed.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Well, he's succeeded in impressing half the world.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: It is my duty to see that he doesn't impress the other half. Rick, Laszlo must never reach America. He stays in Casablanca.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: It'll be interesting to see how he manages.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Manages what?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: His escape.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Oh, but I just told you. -\\-

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: -- Stop it. He escaped from a concentration camp and the Nazis have been chasing him all over Europe.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: This is the end of the chase.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Twenty thousand francs says it isn't.

scene.dir: They sit down to discuss the matter in earnest.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Is that a serious offer?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I just paid out twenty. I'd like to get it back.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Make it ten. I am only a poor corrupt official.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Okay.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Done. No matter how clever he is, he still needs an exit visa, or I should say, two.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Why two?

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: He is traveling with a lady.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: He'll take one.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: I think not. I have seen the lady. And if he did not leave her in Marseilles, or in Oran, he certainly won't leave her in Casablanca.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Maybe he's not quite as romantic as you are.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: It doesn't matter. There is no exit visa for him.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Louis, whatever gave you the impression that I might be interested in helping Laszlo escape?

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Because, my dear Ricky, I suspect that under that cynical shell you're at heart a sentimentalist.

scene.dir: Rick makes a face.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Oh, laugh if you will, but I happen to be familiar with your record. Let me point out just two items. In 1935 you ran guns to Ethiopia. In 1936, you fought in Spain on the Loyalist side.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: And got well paid for it on both occasions.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: The winning side would have paid you much better.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Maybe. Well, it seems you are determined to keep Laszlo here.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: I have my orders.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Oh, I see. Gestapo spank.

scene.dir: Renault stands up.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: My dear Ricky, you overestimate the influence of the Gestapo. I don't interfere with them and they don't interfere with me. In Casablanca I am master of my fate. I am captain of my --

scene.dir: He stops short as his AIDE enters.

sp.speaker: AIDE
sp.diag: -- Major Strasser is here, sir.

scene.dir: Renault starts to leave.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Yeah, you were saying?

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: hurriedly Excuse me.

scene.dir: He hurries away. Rick smiles cynically.

scene.setting: INT. RICK'S CAFE - MAIN ROOM - NIGHT Renault walks up to Carl.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Carl, see that Major Strasser gets a good table, one close to the ladies.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: I have already given him the best, knowing he is German and would take it anyway.

scene.dir: Renault walks over to one of his officers.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Take him quietly. Two guards at every door.

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.diag: Yes, sir. Everything is ready, sir.

scene.dir: The officer salutes and goes off to speak to the guards. Renault walks over to Strasser's table as Rick comes down the stairs.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Good evening, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: Good evening, Captain.

sp.speaker: HEINZE
sp.diag: Won't you join us?

scene.dir: Renault sits down.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Thank you. It is a pleasure to have you here, Major.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: to the waiter Champagne and a tin of caviar.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: May I recommend Veuve Cliquot '26, a good French wine.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: Thank you.

sp.speaker: WAITER
sp.diag: Very well, sir.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: A very interesting club.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Especially so tonight, Major. In a few minutes you will see the arrest of the man who murdered your couriers.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: I expected no less, Captain.

scene.setting: INT. RICK'S CAFE - GAMBLING ROOM - NIGHT Ugarte stands at the roulette table. Two gendarmes approach him from behind.

sp.speaker: GENDARME
sp.diag: Monsieur Ugarte?

scene.dir: Ugarte looks around.

sp.speaker: UGARTE
sp.diag: Oh. Yes?

sp.speaker: GENDARME
sp.diag: Will you please come with us.

sp.speaker: UGARTE
sp.diag: Certainly. May I first please cash my chips?

scene.dir: The officer nods. They follow Ugarte to the cashier's window. Ugarte puts his chips through the window to the CASHIER.

sp.speaker: UGARTE
sp.diag: Pretty lucky, huh? Two thousand, please.

scene.dir: Two more guards station themselves at the door in case there is trouble.

sp.speaker: CASHIER
sp.diag: Two thousand.

sp.speaker: UGARTE
sp.diag: Thank you.

scene.dir: Ugarte starts to walk out, followed by the gendarmes. When he reaches the doorway he suddenly rushes through and slams the door behind himself.

scene.setting: INT. RICK'S CAFE - MAIN ROOM - NIGHT By the time the gendarmes manage to get the door open again, Ugarte has pulled a gun. He FIRES at the doorway. The SHOTS bring on pandemonium in the cafe. As Ugarte runs through the hallway he sees Rick, appearing from the opposite direction, and grabs him.

sp.speaker: UGARTE
sp.diag: Rick! Rick, help me!

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Don't be a fool. You can't get away.

sp.speaker: UGARTE
sp.diag: Rick, hide me. Do something! You must help me, Rick. Do something!

scene.dir: Guards and gendarmes rush in and grab Ugarte. Rick stands impassively as they drag Ugarte off.

sp.speaker: UGARTE
sp.diag: Rick! Rick!

scene.dir: We move to Strasser's table, who has witnessed the event.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: Excellent, Captain.

scene.dir: Back to Rick, still standing where he was, as a CUSTOMER walks by.

sp.speaker: CUSTOMER
sp.diag: When they come to get me, Rick, I hope you'll be more of a help.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I stick my neck out for nobody.

scene.dir: Rick comes out to the middle of the floor. An air of tense expectancy pervades the room. A few customers are on the point of leaving. Rick speaks in a very calm voice.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I'm sorry there was a disturbance, folks, but it's all over now. Everything's all right. Just sit down and have a good time. Enjoy yourself.

scene.dir: Rick glances toward Sam.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: All right, Sam.

scene.dir: Sam nods and begins to play. Renault, Strasser, and Heinze sit calmly at their table after witnessing the arrest. Rick walks by.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: calling to Rick Oh, Rick?

scene.dir: Rick stops and comes over to their table.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Rick, this is Major Heinrich Strasser of the Third Reich.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: How do you do, Mr. Rick?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Oh, how do you do?

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: And you already know Herr Heinze of the Third Reich.

scene.dir: Rick nods to Strasser and Heinze.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: Please join us, Mr. Rick.

scene.dir: Rick sits down with them.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: We are very honored tonight, Rick. Major Strasser is one of the reasons the Third Reich enjoys the reputation it has today.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: You repeat "Third Reich" as though you expected there to be others.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Well, personally, Major, I will take what comes.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: to Rick Do you mind if I ask you a few questions? Unofficially, of course.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Make it official, if you like.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: What is your nationality?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: pokerfaced I'm a drunkard.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: That makes Rick a citizen of the world.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I was born in New York City if that'll help you any.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: I understand you came here from Paris at the time of the occupation.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: There seems to be no secret about that.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: Are you one of those people who cannot imagine the Germans in their beloved Paris?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: It's not particularly my beloved Paris.

sp.speaker: HEINZE
sp.diag: Can you imagine us in London?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: When you get there, ask me.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Ho, diplomatist!

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: How about New York?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Well, there are certain sections of New York, Major, that I wouldn't advise you to try to invade.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: Aha. Who do you think will win the war?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I haven't the slightest idea.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Rick is completely neutral about everything. And that takes in the field of women, too.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: You weren't always so carefully neutral. We have a complete dossier on you.

scene.dir: Strasser takes a little black book from his pocket and turns to a certain page.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: "Richard Blaine, American. Age, thirty-seven. Cannot return to his country."

scene.dir: Strasser looks up from the book

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: The reason is a little vague. We also know what you did in Paris, Mr. Blaine, and also we know why you left Paris.

scene.dir: Rick reaches over and takes the book from Strasser's hand.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: Don't worry. We are not going to broadcast it.

scene.dir: Rick looks up from the book.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Are my eyes really brown?

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: You will forgive my curiosity, Mr. Blaine. The point is, an enemy of the Reich has come to Casablanca and we are checking up on anybody who can be of any help to us.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: glances toward Renault My interest in whether Victor Laszlo stays or goes is purely a sporting one.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: In this case, you have no sympathy for the fox, huh?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Not particularly. I understand the point of view of the hound, too.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: Victor Laszlo published the foulest lies in the Prague newspapers until the very day we marched in, and even after that he continued to print scandal sheets in a cellar.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Of course, one must admit he has great courage.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: I admit he is very clever. Three times he slipped through our fingers. In Paris he continued his activities. We intend not to let it happen again.

scene.dir: Rick gets up.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: You'll excuse me, gentlemen. Your business is politics. Mine is running a saloon.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: Good evening, Mr. Blaine.

scene.dir: Rick walks away toward the gambling room.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: You see, Major, you have nothing to worry about Rick.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: Perhaps.

scene.dir: A couple comes in the front door. They are VICTOR LASZLO, the Czech resistance leader, and a very pretty young woman wearing a simple white gown, MISS ILSA LUND. She is so beautiful, in fact, that people turn to stare. The HEADWAITER comes up to them.

sp.speaker: HEADWAITER
sp.diag: Yes, Monsieur?

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: I reserved a table. Victor Laszlo.

sp.speaker: HEADWAITER
sp.diag: Yes, Monsieur Laszlo. Right this way.

scene.dir: As the headwaiter takes them to a table they pass by the piano, and the woman looks at Sam. Sam, with a conscious effort, keeps his eyes on the keyboard as they go past. He appears to know this woman. After she has gone by Sam steals a look in her direction. BERGER, a slight, middle-aged man, observes the couple from a distance. The headwaiter seats Ilsa. Laszlo takes the chair opposite and surveys the room. Strasser and Renault look up at them from their table.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Two cointreaux, please.

sp.speaker: WAITER
sp.diag: Yes, Monsieur.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: to Ilsa I saw no one of Ugarte's description.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Victor, I, I feel somehow we shouldn't stay here.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: If we would walk out so soon, it would only call attention to us. Perhaps Ugarte's in some other part of the cafe.

scene.dir: Berger walks up to their table.

sp.speaker: BERGER
sp.diag: Excuse me, but you look like a couple who are on their way to America.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Well?

scene.dir: Berger takes a ring from his finger.

sp.speaker: BERGER
sp.diag: You will find a market there for this ring. I am forced to sell it at a great sacrifice.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Thank you, but I hardly think --

sp.speaker: BERGER
sp.diag: -- Then perhaps for the lady. The ring is quite unique.

scene.dir: He holds it down for their view. Carefully lifting up the stone, he reveals-- INSERT - a gold plate in the setting underneath, an impression of the Lorraine Cross of General de Gaulle.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Oh, yes, I'm very interested.

scene.dir: Berger sits down with them.

sp.speaker: BERGER
sp.diag: Good.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: lower voice What is your name?

sp.speaker: BERGER
sp.diag: Berger, Norwegian, and at your service, sir.

scene.dir: Renault approaches the table from behind Laszlo. Ilsa tries to warn him.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Victor--

scene.dir: Laszlo understands.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: in a low voice I'll meet you in a few minutes at the bar. in a louder voice I do not think we want to buy the ring. But thank you for showing it to us.

scene.dir: Berger, taking the cue, sighs and puts the ring away.s

sp.speaker: BERGER
sp.diag: Such a bargain. But that is your decision?

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: I'm sorry. It is..

scene.dir: Berger gets up and leaves as Renault moves to the table

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Monsieur Laszlo, is it not?

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Yes.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: I am Captain Renault, Prefect of Police.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Yes. What is it you want?

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: amiably Merely to welcome you to Casablanca and wish you a pleasant stay. It is not often we have so distinguished a visitor.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Thank you. I hope you'll forgive me, Captain, but the present French administration has not always been so cordial. May I present Miss Ilsa Lund?

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: I was informed you were the most beautiful woman ever to visit Casablanca. That was a gross understatement.

scene.dir: Ilsa's manner is friendly and reserved, her voice low and soft.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: You are very kind.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Won't you join us?

scene.dir: He sits down.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: If you will permit me. calls to the waiter Oh, Emil. Please, a bottle of your best champagne, and put it on my bill.

sp.speaker: EMIL
sp.diag: Very well, sir.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: No, Captain, please.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: No. Please, Monsieur, it is a little game we play. They put it on the bill, I tear the bill up. It is very convenient.

scene.dir: Ilsa glances off in Sam's direction.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Captain, the boy who is playing the piano, somewhere I have seen him.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Sam?

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Yes.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: He came from Paris with Rick.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Rick? Who's he?

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: smiling Mademoiselle, you are in Rick's and Rick is --

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: -- Is what?

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Well, Mademoiselle, he's the kind of a man that, well, if I were a woman and I-- taps his chest were not around, I should be in love with Rick. But what a fool I am talking to a beautiful woman about another man.

scene.dir: Renault jumps to his feet as Strasser enters.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Excuse me. Ah, Major. Mademoiselle Lund, Monsieur Laszlo, may I present Major Heinrich Strasser.

scene.dir: Strasser bows and smiles pleasantly.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: How do you do. This is a pleasure I have long looked forward to.

scene.dir: There is not the slightest recognition from either Ilsa or Laszlo. Strasser waits to be asked to seat himself.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: I'm sure you'll excuse me if I am not gracious, but you see, Major Strasser, I'm a Czechoslovakian.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: You were a Czechoslovakian. Now you are a subject of the German Reich!

scene.dir: Laszlo stands.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: I've never accepted that privilege, and I'm now on French soil.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: I should like to discuss some matters arising from your presence on French soil.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: This is hardly the time or the place.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: hardening Then we shall state another time and another place. Tomorrow at ten in the Prefect's office, with Mademoiselle.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Captain Renault, I am under your authority. Is it your order that we come to your office?

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: amiably Let us say that it is my request. That is a much more pleasant word.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Very well.

scene.dir: Renault and Strasser bow shortly.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Mademoiselle.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: Mademoiselle. Renault and Strasser walk away.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: A very clever tactical retreat, Major.

scene.dir: Strasser looks at Renault sharply, but sees only a noncommittal smile on Renault's face. Laszlo remains standing at the table as Strasser and Renault leave.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: This time they really mean to stop me.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Victor, I'm afraid for you.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: We have been in difficult places before, haven't we?

scene.dir: Ilsa smiles back at him, but her eyes are still troubled. On the floor, CORINA strums a guitar and begins her number. Meanwhile, Laszlo looks about with apparent casualness. He sees Strasser and Renault whispering together, then notices Berger at the bar.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: I must find out what Berger knows.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Be careful.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: I will, don't worry.

scene.dir: He rises and goes off. We see Ilsa's troubled profile. While Corinna sings, Sam gives a worried glance in Ilsa's direction. Ilsa watches him. At the bar, Berger sips a drink. Laszlo walks up and casually takes a place at the bar next to Berger.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Mr. Berger, the ring, could I see it again?

sp.speaker: BERGER
sp.diag: Yes, Monsieur.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: to Sacha A champagne cocktail, please.

scene.dir: Laszlo takes the ring and looks at it.

sp.speaker: BERGER
sp.diag: in a low voice I recognize you from the news photographs, Monsieur Laszlo.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: In a concentration camp, one is apt to lose a little weight.

sp.speaker: BERGER
sp.diag: We read five times that you were killed in five different places.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: smiles wryly As you see, it was true every single time. Thank heaven I found you, Berger. I am looking for a man by the name of Ugarte. He is supposed to help me.

scene.dir: Berger shakes his head.

sp.speaker: BERGER
sp.diag: Ugarte cannot even help himself, Monsieur. He is under arrest for murder. He was arrested here tonight.

scene.dir: Laszlo absorbs the shock quietly.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: I see.

sp.speaker: BERGER
sp.diag: with intense devotion But we who are still free will do all we can. We are organized, Monsieur, underground like everywhere else. Tomorrow night there is a meeting at the Caverne du Bois. If you would come--

scene.dir: He stops when Sacha brings the drink to Laszlo. Corina finishes her song, and the crowd applauds quite enthusiastically. Ilsa sits alone at her table.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: to waiter Will you ask the piano player to come over here, please?

sp.speaker: WAITER
sp.diag: Very well, Mademoiselle.

scene.dir: Renault comes up to the bar near Berger and Laszlo.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: How's the jewelry business, Berger?

sp.speaker: BERGER
sp.diag: Er, not so good. to Sacha May I have my check, please?

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Too bad you weren't here earlier, Monsieur Laszlo. We had quite a bit of excitement this evening, didn't we, Berger?

sp.speaker: BERGER
sp.diag: Er, yes. Excuse me, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: My bill.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: No. Two champagne cocktails, please.

sp.speaker: SACHA
sp.diag: Yes, sir.

scene.dir: Sam wheels in the piano to Ilsa's table. On his face is that funny fear. Ilsa herself is not as self-possessed as she tries to appear. There is something behind this, some mystery.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Hello, Sam.

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: Hello, Miss Ilsa. I never expected to see you again.

scene.dir: He sits down and is ready to play.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: It's been a long time.

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: Yes, ma'am. A lot of water under the bridge.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Some of the old songs, Sam.

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: Yes, ma'am.

scene.dir: Sam begins to play a number. He is nervous, waiting for anything.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Where is Rick?

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: evading I don't know. I ain't seen him all night. .

scene.dir: Sam looks very uncomfortable

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: When will he be back?

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: Not tonight no more. He ain't coming. Uh, he went home.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Does he always leave so early?

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: Oh, he never-- well-- desperately he's got a girl up at the Blue Parrot. He goes up there all the time.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: You used to be a much better liar, Sam.

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: Leave him alone, Miss Ilsa. You're bad luck to him.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Play it once, Sam, for old time's sake.

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: I don't know what you mean, Miss Ilsa.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Play it, Sam. Play "As Time Goes By."

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: Oh I can't remember it, Miss Ilsa. I'm a little rusty on it.

scene.dir: Of course he can. He doesn't want to play it. He seems even more scared now.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: I'll hum it for you.

scene.dir: Ilsa starts to hum. Sam begins to play it very softly.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Sing it, Sam.

scene.dir: And Sam sings.

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: You must remember this, A kiss is just a kiss, A sigh is just a sigh, The fundamental things apply, As time goes by.

scene.dir: The door to the gambling room opens. Rick comes swinging out. He's heard the music and he's livid.

sp.speaker: SAM
sp.diag: And when two lovers woo, They both say I love you, On that you can rely, No matter what the future brings, As time goes by.

scene.dir: Rick walks briskly up to the piano.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Sam, I thought I told you never to play--

scene.dir: As he sees Ilsa he stops short. Sam stops playing. Two close-ups reveal Ilsa and Rick seeing each other. Rick appears shocked. For a long moment he just looks at her. Sam prepares to move the piano away. Renault and Laszlo approach the table from the bar.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: to Ilsa Well, you were asking about Rick and here he is. Mademoiselle, may I present --

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: -- Hello, Ilsa.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Hello, Rick.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Oh, you've already met Rick, Mademoiselle?

scene.dir: There's no answer from either.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Well then, perhaps you also ---

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: -- This is Mr. Laszlo.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: How do you do?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: How do you do?

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: One hears a great deal about Rick in Casablanca.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: And about Victor Laszlo everywhere.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Won't you join us for a drink?

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: laughing Oh, no, Rick never --

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: -- Thanks. I will.

scene.dir: Rick sits down.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Well! A precedent is being broken. Er, Emil!

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: This is a very interesting cafe. I congratulate you.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: And I congratulate you.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: What for?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Your work.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Thank you. I try.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: We all try. You succeed.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: I can't get over you two. She was asking about you earlier, Rick, in a way that made me extremely jealous.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: to Rick I wasn't sure you were the same. Let's see, the last time we met --

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: -- It was "La Belle Aurore."

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: How nice. You remembered. But of course, that was the day the Germans marched into Paris.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Not an easy day to forget.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: No.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I remember every detail. The Germans wore gray, you wore blue.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Yes. I put that dress away. When the Germans march out, I'll wear it again.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Ricky, you're becoming quite human. I suppose we have to thank you for that, Mademoiselle.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Ilsa, I don't wish to be the one to say it, but it's late.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: glancing at his wristwatch So it is. And we have a curfew here in Casablanca. It would never do for the Chief of Police to be found drinking after hours and have to fine himself.

scene.dir: Rick and Ilsa look at each other. Laszlo signals the waiter

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: I hope we didn't overstay our welcome.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Not at all.

sp.speaker: WAITER
sp.diag: to Laszlo Your check, sir. Rick takes the check.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: to waiter Oh, it's my party.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Another precedent gone. This has been a very interesting evening. I'll call you a cab. Gasoline rationing, time of night.

scene.dir: Renault leaves.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: We'll come again.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Any time.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Say goodnight to Sam for me.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I will.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: There's still nobody in the world who can play "As Time Goes By" like Sam.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: He hasn't played it in a long time.

scene.dir: Ilsa smiles.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Goodnight.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Goodnight.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Goodnight.

scene.dir: Rick and Laszlo nod goodnight to each other. Laszlo and Ilsa start to the door as Rick sits down again and stares off in their direction.
